qas.question: By what date did Sony correct the issue with the system clock?
What were the broken models mistakenly classifying 2010 as?
What storage system for dates led to the system clock error?
What clock unrelated to the error in the PS3 had to be updated in some cases in order to fix the bug?
By what date did Sony correct the issue with the system disk?
What were the broken models mistakenly classifying 2011 as?
What storage system for dates led to the system disk error?
What clock unrelated to the error in the PS2 had to be updated in some cases in order to fix the bug?
What clock unrelated to the error in the PS3 had to be updated in some cases in order to continue the bug?

context: Sony confirmed that there was an error and stated that they were narrowing down the issue and were continuing to work to restore service. By <a0_0><b4_0>March 2 (UTC), 2010<b4_0/><a0_0/>, owners of original PS3 models could connect to PSN successfully and the clock no longer showed December 31, 1999. Sony stated that the affected models incorrectly identified 2010 as <a1_0><b5_0>a leap year<b5_0/><a1_0/>, because of a bug in the <a2_0><b6_0>BCD<b6_0/><a2_0/> method of storing the date. However, for some users, the hardware's <a3_0><b7_0><b8_0>operating system clock<b8_0/><b7_0/><a3_0/> (mainly updated from the internet and not associated with the internal clock) needed to be updated manually or by re-syncing it via the internet.
